tossups.question: This novel's protagonist tells his lover that he dreams of "a grave, deep and narrow, where we could clasp each other in our arms." This novel ends with that lover holding out a "trembling hand," and speaking with "great difficulty," but ends mid-sentence before telling "what she said." This novel's protagonist calls both of his assistants Arthur, because he cannot tell Arthur and Jeremiah apart. The protagonist of this novel seeks the company of the messenger Barnabas, whose sister Olga takes him to the Herrenhof. The mysterious Count Westwest supposedly employs the protagonist of this novel, who is never able to meet with Klamm despite the "interrogations" of his bureaucratic secretaries. For 10 points, name this novel about the surveyor K's repeated attempts to access the title structure, an unfinished novel by Franz Kafka.
tossups.formatted_answer: The Castle [or Das Schloss]
tossups.answer: The Castle [or Das Schloss]

tossups.question: An aspect of this effect was observed using two point discharge counters by Walther Bothe (VAL-tur BO-tur) in his Nobel-winning first use of coincidence circuits. Observations of this effect helped to rapidly disprove the BKS theory. A sharp cutoff in plots of spectrophotometry results is called this effect's namesake "edge." An opposite form of this phenomenon can be used to detect galaxy clusters, because it causes CMB distortion in the related Sunyaev-Zeldovich (SOON-yie-ev-ZEL-doe-vitch) effect. This effect, whose low-energy analog is named for Thomson, has a characteristic value equal to "Planck's constant over mass times the speed of light." This effect produces a shift proportional to "1 minus cosine theta" in its namesake wavelength for X-rays and gamma rays. A photon is deflected by an electron in - for 10 points - what type of scattering named for an American physicist?
tossups.formatted_answer: Compton effect [or Compton scattering or inverse Compton scattering; or Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect or S-Z effect until "Sunyaev-Zeldovich" is read]
tossups.answer: Compton effect [or Compton scattering or inverse Compton scattering; or Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect or S-Z effect until "Sunyaev-Zeldovich" is read]

tossups.question: Archibald Hinshelwood, a supporter of this law, wrote of finding no "such turbulent spirit" among Nova Scotians like the "violent spirit of opposition" that arose against this law elsewhere. The "Twelve Immortal Justices" are commemorated on "Repudiation Day" for actions regarding this legislation. William Bradford created the "Tombstone Edition" in response to this legislation. The Loyal Nine encouraged Ebenezer Mackintosh to lead a mob that hung effigies of Andrew Oliver on a "Liberty Tree" to protest this legislation. The Declaratory Act accompanied the repeal of this legislation. In response to this legislation, a namesake "Congress" produced the "Declaration of Rights and Grievances," which laid out the position of "no taxation without representation". For 10 points, name this 1765 law that created a tax on colonial American paper goods.
tossups.formatted_answer: Stamp Act of 1765 [or the Duties in American Colonies Act of 1765; or Stamp Act Congress]
tossups.answer: Stamp Act of 1765 [or the Duties in American Colonies Act of 1765; or Stamp Act Congress]

tossups.question: This designer created specialized greeting cards called zinzins. This designer would choose his favorite models by giving them a heart pendant with no Swarovski crystals. Pink bodies and giant lips appear on a haute couture collection by this designer inspired by Tom Wesselmann. This designer created a knit wedding dress that resembled a Russian nesting doll. Due in part to the failure of a beatnik-inspired line he created, this designer left the House of Dior despite being Christian Dior's handpicked successor. This designer of the Trapeze dress created cocktail dresses with patterns based on of the paintings of Piet Mondrian, as well as the first tuxedo for women. For 10 points, name this French fashion designer who designed the Le Smoking tuxedo and founded a fashion house whose acronym is YSL.
tossups.formatted_answer: Yves Saint-Laurent [Yves Henri Donat Mathieu-Saint-Laurent; accept YSL until it is read]
tossups.answer: Yves Saint-Laurent [Yves Henri Donat Mathieu-Saint-Laurent; accept YSL until it is read]

tossups.question: When a prop featuring this creature was prematurely pulled offstage, tenor Leo Slezak turned to the soprano and asked "when does the next [one] leave?" In the Allegro molto third movement finale of a symphony in E-flat, a tremolando melody begun in the strings gives way to a "noble" motif in thirds named for these animals and introduced by the horns. The melody for a scene featuring these animals begins moderato with an oboe playing long F-sharp, rising legato eighths "B C-sharp D E," long F-sharp; after that scene, the hero breaks his crossbow. At the end of the opera, Lohengrin departs in a boat pulled by these animals. This animal, which names a "hymn" motif in Sibelius's fifth symphony, is represented by a cor anglaise ("CORE" AHN-glay) in the second tone poem in the Lemminkainen Suite. For 10 points, Odette becomes what bird in a Tchaikovsky ballet?
tossups.formatted_answer: swans [or whooper swans; or swan-call motif; or "swan hymn"; or Swan Lake; or The Swan of Tuonela; prompt on birds]
tossups.answer: swans [or whooper swans; or swan-call motif; or "swan hymn"; or Swan Lake; or The Swan of Tuonela; prompt on birds]

tossups.question: In a play in this language, the Four Daughters of God debate the fate of a man protected from Belial by the title structure. A play in this language begins with Gill hiding a stolen sheep as her newborn in a cradle before its title characters offer cherries, a bird, and a ball to Jesus. A Buddhist tale of fake friends became a play whose best-known version is in this language, in which a man's Kindred and Cousin refuse to accompany him to a summons by Death. The Castle of Perseverance and the Second Shepherds' Play are in this language, used for a play likely translated from Dutch whose title character is abandoned by Knowledge and Strength but is accompanied to heaven by Good Deeds. For 10 points, name this language of the play Everyman, which succeeded its "Old" form and gave way to the "Early Modern" language of Elizabethan drama.
tossups.formatted_answer: Middle English [or ME; prompt on English]
tossups.answer: Middle English [or ME; prompt on English]

tossups.question: During a 1790s insurrection, this kingdom's subjects identified foreign officials by the pronunciation of the word for "chickpea." The Carta de Logu was a legal code promulgated by one of this kingdom's medieval predecessors, the Judicate of Arborea. A unit of sharpshooters originating from this kingdom adorns their hats with black grouse feathers and is known for running marches. This kingdom's Stamenti parliament was abolished following the Perfect Fusion. One of this kingdom's last monarchs lends its name to the 1848 Albertine Statute. The Savoyards stylized this kingdom's heir apparent as the Prince of Piedmont up until its reigning king Victor Emmanuel II was proclaimed King of Italy in 1861. For 10 points, identify this kingdom named for a now-Italian island south of Corsica.
tossups.formatted_answer: Kingdom of Sardinia [or Piedmont-Sardinia or Savoy-Sardinia; or Kingdom of Piedmont until it is read; or the Sardinian Vespers; do not accept the "Duchy of Savoy"]
tossups.answer: Kingdom of Sardinia [or Piedmont-Sardinia or Savoy-Sardinia; or Kingdom of Piedmont until it is read; or the Sardinian Vespers; do not accept the "Duchy of Savoy"]

tossups.question: Supply of this element's oxide for use in pigments may be termed "American grade" if it was isolated with the direct process instead of the French process. Water reactors use the depleted form of this element's oxide as a corrosion inhibitor, though its predominant industrial use is as an accelerator in vulcanization. It's not tin, but Zamak alloys are prone to this element's namesake "pest," a form of corrosion often conflated with white rust. Commonly used in phosphorescent pigments, this element's sulfide forms a namesake "blende" structure and is found with iron in sphalerite. This metal takes on a characteristic spangle pattern following one "hot-dip" industrial process. That corrosion-resistant layer of this metal is used to make galvanized steel. For 10 points, what transition metal alloys with copper to form brass?
tossups.formatted_answer: zinc [or Zn]
tossups.answer: zinc [or Zn]

tossups.question: Harold Hotelling names a form of this quantity maximized by his namesake rule concerning non-renewable resources. The low cost of a process named for this quantity relative to the gains is the subject of the Tullock paradox. This quantity equals "Y times quantity p minus c, all minus Y F m" in the von Thunen model. This quantity equals the payment in excess of the cost of the use of a factor of production. A law of subsistence wages that is sometimes attributed to Ricardo derives from his law of this quantity. A person who stretches a chain across a river and charges ships to lower it exemplifies an agent who increases their proportion of wealth without increasing total wealth, and is thus "seeking" this quantity. For 10 points, name this type of "unearned income" whose name derives from the payments tenant farmers give to landlords.
tossups.formatted_answer: economic rent [accept rent-seeking]
tossups.answer: economic rent [accept rent-seeking]

tossups.question: To reconstruct a sculpture by this artist, Adolf Furtwängler ("FYOORT-vain-glur") attached a head from the Pelagio Palagi to a body kept in Dresden. An inscription calling a wrestler beautiful appears on the little finger of a statue by this artist. Although this artist likely didn't use the number, Mark Barr referenced this sculptor's name when he symbolized the golden ratio. A Lawrence Alma-Tadema painting depicts this artist presenting a frieze of the Panathenaic ("pan-uh-thuh-NAY-ic") games to his friends. Alan LeQuire recreated a sculpture by this artist in the naos of a William Crawford Smith project in Centennial Park, Nashville. This artist and his patron Pericles appear on the shield of a chryselephantine ("chris-ell-uh-FAN-tin") sculpture by him wearing gold and holding a small Nike. For 10 points, name this Athenian sculptor of the Statue of Zeus at Olympia and of the Athena in the Parthenon.
tossups.formatted_answer: Phidias [or Pheidias]
tossups.answer: Phidias [or Pheidias]

tossups.question: This story's protagonist recalls how her family once went on an "expedition" to find a quince (KWINS) tree and decides to look at the relief carvings of a tomb in a Chinese garden. A character decides to buy a "daring" black dress in this story after learning that her daughter might have leukemia. A character in this story remembers the phrase "shoreless seas" while reciting Joaquin Miller's poem "Columbus." That father in this story suddenly remembers that a mythological figure was a cupbearer, not a shepherd. In this story, Don and Judith leave for Mexico and the protagonist reflects on her estrangement from her daughter Nichola. After visiting a Toronto planetarium in this story, Janet quizzes her hospitalized father about the title satellites of a planet. For 10 points, name this short story by Alice Munro.
tossups.formatted_answer: "The Moons of Jupiter"
tossups.answer: "The Moons of Jupiter"

tossups.question: Gavin Flood wrote a popular introduction to this religion, the primary subject of the PhD thesis and early studies of Mircea Eliade (meer-CHAY-uh el-ee-AH-duh). Max Muller repeatedly called for a "reformation" of this non-Christian faith whose writings make up the earliest and largest number of the 50-volume set of Sacred Books he edited. A representative of this religion received a two-minute ovation upon addressing "Sisters and brothers of America" at the 1893 Parliament of the World's Religions in Chicago. The endonym Sanatani is used by members of this title faith of a controversial "alternative history" by Wendy Doniger. Smartism is a denomination of this religion, the largest by number of adherents in Mauritius and Nepal. By population, it is the world's third largest faith, and usually cited as its oldest. For 10 points, name this majority religion of India.
tossups.formatted_answer: Hinduism [or Sanatana Dharma before "Sanatani" is read; or Vedic religion; or The Hindus: An Alternative History; or Shaivism or Shivaism; or Smartism or Smarta tradition before mention] [the "representative" in the third sentence was Swami Vivekananda]
tossups.answer: Hinduism [or Sanatana Dharma before "Sanatani" is read; or Vedic religion; or The Hindus: An Alternative History; or Shaivism or Shivaism; or Smartism or Smarta tradition before mention] [the "representative" in the third sentence was Swami Vivekananda]

tossups.question: At the entrance to an underground transit station, nine people protesting this war were killed by the police after being crushed by iron gratings. Other protesters during this war who were shot and dumped in rivers had their cause of death listed as "drowning in bullets." Alistair Horne wrote the book A Savage War of Peace about this conflict, during which a president ambiguously declared "I have understood you." The return of torture during this war was lamented in the Manifesto of the 121. A bomb that exploded at the Milk Bar Café was planted by the 21-year-old woman Zohra Drif during this war. A mass emigration of harkis (har-keez) and pieds-noirs (pee-ay-NWARZ) occurred after this war, which was ended in 1962 by the Évian (EV-yahn) Accords. The FLN fought against France in, for 10 points, what war that resulted in the independence of a country in North Africa?
tossups.formatted_answer: Algerian War of Independence [or Algerian Revolution; or Guerre d'Algérie; or Thawra Al-Jaza'iriyya; do not accept "Algerian Civil War"]
tossups.answer: Algerian War of Independence [or Algerian Revolution; or Guerre d'Algérie; or Thawra Al-Jaza'iriyya; do not accept "Algerian Civil War"]

tossups.question: Geoffrey of Monmouth wrote that the mythical prince Nennius was buried with one of these objects he took from the Romans during their invasion of Britain. After Astydemia accused Peleus of raping her, Acastus stole one of these objects from Peleus and abandoned him on Mount Pelion, though Chiron later returns it to him. Examples of these items from Roman legend include Crocea Mors, which once belonged to Julius Caesar. Dionysus II of Syracuse relents to his courtier's wish under a condition involving one of these objects attached to a strand of horse hair. Themis, the titan of justice, was often depicted holding a scale in one hand and this type of object in the other. Damocles sat on his king's thrones beneath one of these objects. For 10 points, name this type of weapon with which Perseus beheaded Medusa.
tossups.formatted_answer: sword [prompt on answers like blade]
tossups.answer: sword [prompt on answers like blade]

tossups.question: Likely inspired by a Richard Feynman speech, Steve McConnell labeled a "cargo cult" form of this discipline as being carried out by incompetent "imposter organizations." Ward Cunningham described the cost of future work due to short-term solutions in this discipline as "technical debt." Scott Ambler contributed to a 2001 Manifesto of this discipline which laid out values like "individuals and interactions over processes and tools." The waterfall method was first introduced for this discipline. The "agile" approach to the discipline advocates "continuous testing" and "bare minimum documentation." IT operations are combined with this discipline in DevOps. Github is among the version control tools used in, for 10 points, what discipline, in which products are developed using languages like Java?
tossups.formatted_answer: software development [or software engineering or computer programming or computer coding or writing code, prompt on engineering or development]
tossups.answer: software development [or software engineering or computer programming or computer coding or writing code, prompt on engineering or development]

tossups.question: Nicolae Ceaușescu (chow-CHESK-yoo) paid Carlos the Jackal to bomb the Munich headquarters of one of these organizations whose current logo is an orange torch. Viva América was a program launched by one of these organizations as part of the Good Neighbor Policy. Paul White alleged that newspapers exaggerated a Halloween event caused by one of these organizations to discredit these institutions. Caroline was the name of a "pirate" one of these organizations that the U.K. tried to criminalize with the Marine Offenses Act. Soviet citizens could learn blocked information through one of these organizations with the words "Liberty" and "Free Europe" in its name. The show All Things Considered is distributed by a "National Public" network of these organizations. For 10 points, NPR is what kind of broadcasting organization?
tossups.formatted_answer: radio stations or networks [or public radio; or state-sponsored radio; or any answers describing a radio broadcasting organization; or CBS Radio; or pirate radio; or Radio Caroline; or Radio Free Europe; or Radio Liberty; or National Public Radio; prompt on answers describing broadcasting or news that don't specifically mention radio; prompt on NPR until it is read] [Paul White was talking about Orson Welles's War of the Worlds broadcast.]
tossups.answer: radio stations or networks [or public radio; or state-sponsored radio; or any answers describing a radio broadcasting organization; or CBS Radio; or pirate radio; or Radio Caroline; or Radio Free Europe; or Radio Liberty; or National Public Radio; prompt on answers describing broadcasting or news that don't specifically mention radio; prompt on NPR until it is read] [Paul White was talking about Orson Welles's War of the Worlds broadcast.]

tossups.question: A mere three bones were used to identify an extinct type of this animal with species name micromeros, meaning "small thigh." In addition to the St. Bathan type, there are five extant species of this animal, including great spotted, little spotted, and one that lives in the forests of the Okarito area. Predators of this animal, such as stoats, are managed using the toxin sodium fluoroacetate, which is also called 1080. This animal, which makes up the genus Apteryx (AP-tuh-riks), is used to make a cloak called a kahu (KAH-hoo). This smallest ratite ("RAT-tight"), which resembles the weka (WEY-kuh), lays large eggs that are up to a quarter of the weight of the female. This nocturnal bird has nostrils at the end of its long beak. Hair-like feathers are possessed by, for 10 points, what flightless brown bird that is found in New Zealand?
tossups.formatted_answer: kiwis [or St. Bathans kiwis or great spotted kiwis or little spotted kiwis or Okarito brown kiwis or roroas or rowis or tokoekas; accept Apteryx or Proapteryx or Proapteryx micromeros or Apteryx haastii or Apteryx owenii or Apteryx rowi before "Apteryx" is mentioned; prompt on birds or Aves or ratites; prompt on P. micromeros or A. haasti or A. owenii or A. rowi before "Apteryx" is mentioned by asking "what is its genus name?"]
tossups.answer: kiwis [or St. Bathans kiwis or great spotted kiwis or little spotted kiwis or Okarito brown kiwis or roroas or rowis or tokoekas; accept Apteryx or Proapteryx or Proapteryx micromeros or Apteryx haastii or Apteryx owenii or Apteryx rowi before "Apteryx" is mentioned; prompt on birds or Aves or ratites; prompt on P. micromeros or A. haasti or A. owenii or A. rowi before "Apteryx" is mentioned by asking "what is its genus name?"]

tossups.question: This thinker criticized the "argument from reason" presented in the third chapter of another thinker's work Miracles, prompting C. S. Lewis to revise it. This thinker controversially claimed that the pronoun "I" is non-referring. This thinker criticized the distinction between wartime killing and murder in a discussion of the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki titled "Mr. Truman's Degree." This thinker posited an "institutional context" of a fact that can be "brute relative to" a set of other facts. The "aretaic (ah-ruh-TAY-ick) turn" is often traced to this philosopher's revival of the field of virtue ethics in a paper which coined the term "consequentialism". Many of Ludwig Wittgenstein's posthumous works were edited and translated into English by, for 10 points, what philosopher who wrote "Modern Moral Philosophy" and "Intention?"
tossups.formatted_answer: (Gertrude) Elizabeth (Margaret) Anscombe [or G. E. M. Anscombe]
tossups.answer: (Gertrude) Elizabeth (Margaret) Anscombe [or G. E. M. Anscombe]

tossups.question: A sport developed in this city that resembles an open-court version of squash is the pelota variant of paleta frontón ("fron-TON"). The term "streets in the sky" refers to this city's tradition of ornate balconies, one of which adorns its Palacio de Torre Tagle ("pah-LASS-ee-oh day TOH-ray TAG-lay"). Each October, hundreds of thousands of people follow a parade in this city of a painting of Christ called the "Lord of Miracles," which survived three massive earthquakes. The oldest continuously-operating university in the Americas is this city's National University of San Marcos. This city was built across the valleys of the Chillón ("shill-ON"), Lurín ("loo-REEN"), and Rímac ("REE-mack") rivers in a coastal desert zone. The nearby port of Callao ("kye-OW") serves this so-called "City of Kings," whose name means "speaker" in Quechua ("KETCH-wa"). Francisco Pizarro founded, for 10 points, what capital city of Peru?
tossups.formatted_answer: Lima
tossups.answer: Lima

tossups.question: Though Verna Arvey finished this writer's libretto for the opera Troubled Island, this author wrote all the text for "Simon Bore the Cross," composed by frequent collaborator Margaret Bonds. This poet called love "a naked shadow on a gnarled and naked tree" in a "Song" whose three stanzas open "Way Down South in Dixie." One of this poet's characters, who "can't be satisfied" and wants to put his "troubles on the shelf," sings "I wish that I had died." In response to Walt Whitman's "I Hear America Singing," this author wrote, "They'll see how beautiful I am and be ashamed–" in a poem whose speaker boasts, "Tomorrow, I'll be at the table when company comes." This poet described how "the stars went out" while hearing a singer "down on Lenox Avenue." For 10 points, name this Harlem Renaissance poet of "I, Too" and "The Weary Blues."
tossups.formatted_answer: Langston Hughes
tossups.answer: Langston Hughes

tossups.question: While in the Frankie Fairfax Orchestra, this musician received a popular nickname after carrying his instrument in a paper bag. The dancers Stump and Stumpy notoriously damaged this musician's instrument. This composer of "Pickin' the Cabbage" recorded it under Cab Calloway, at whom he may have thrown a spitball in a conflict over this man's "Chinese music" that led him to assault Cab with a knife. For transcribing other music by this composer, Frank Paparelli has co-writing credit for his song originally titled "Interlude." "Groovin' High" is by this composer, who repeatedly employed a jump from low to high F in another standard. With Charlie Parker, this composer of "Salt Peanuts" is credited with inventing bebop. For 10 points, "A Night in Tunisia" is by what musician who puffed his cheeks while playing a signature bent trumpet?
tossups.formatted_answer: Dizzy Gillespie [or Dizzy; or Diz; or Birks; or John Birks Gillespie]
tossups.answer: Dizzy Gillespie [or Dizzy; or Diz; or Birks; or John Birks Gillespie]

bonuses.leadin: In the 1900s, this kingdom engaged in a pork-based trade war with its northern neighbor, whose imports once made up 90% of this country's foreign trade. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this kingdom whose monarch Peter I came to power in 1903 following the Apis-orchestrated May Coup.
Peter I's ascension to the Serbian throne marked the end of this royal dynasty, which rivaled the Karađorđević family for control since the first Serbian Uprising in the 1810s.

In 1918, Peter I's kingdom expanded to form Yugoslavia, composed of Serbs, Croats, and this ethnic group. This ethnic group's namesake republic, which includes Melania Trump's birthplace in Novo Mesto, was the first country to break from Yugoslavia in 1990.

bonuses.leadin: Protogenes admitted defeat to Apelles in a competition to paint the finest one of these things. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these shapes used in perspective to make objects appear closer or further. They can extend out infinitely in both directions.

This artist claimed that lines produce a composition by interacting on the "basic plane" in his Point and Line to Plane. This artist wished for other painters to express their inner lives through abstraction and music and warned "art has no noble champion" in another book.

These solid-colored vertical lines attempt to "unify" canvases like Vir Heroicus Sublimis by creating division. Two of these lines appear on the edges of the painting Who's Afraid of Red, Yellow, and Blue.

bonuses.leadin: CstF promotes the formation of a polyadenine tail on these molecules, whose expression can be regulated by their five-prime and three-prime U·T·Rs. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this molecule. In eukaryotes, these molecules have five-prime caps.
In prokaryotes, but not eukaryotes, a single mRNA can encode multiple proteins. An mRNA molecule that codes for multiple proteins is given this name.

This classification system divides viruses into groups based on how they synthesize mRNA. This system is named for a former president of Caltech who won the 1975 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.
answers: mRNA [or messenger RNA or messenger ribonucleic acid; prompt on RNA or ribonucleic acid]
formatted_answers: mRNA [or messenger RNA or messenger ribonucleic acid; prompt on RNA or ribonucleic acid]

bonuses.leadin: In Pharos and Pharillon, E.M. Forster described this poet as a "gentleman in a straw hat, standing absolutely motionless at a slight angle to the universe." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this resident of Alexandria, which is the setting of his poem "The God Abandons Antony." He wrote of "a kind of solution" posed by the title people in his poem "Waiting for the Barbarians."
Like Yiannis Ritsos, Cavafy wrote in the modern form of this language whose earlier Koine form is also called "Alexandrian" or "common Attic."

Mikis Theodorakis's setting of this Greek author's poem "Denial" was sung by crowds at his funeral. A stanza from his Mythistorema beginning "I woke with this marble head in my hands" was recited at the 2004 Olympics opening ceremony.

bonuses.leadin: Tensions between Uyghurs and this ethnic group resulted in the Kizil Massacre, after which they massacred Uyghurs in revenge at the Battle of Kashgar. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this minority whose communities built the largest number of nusi, or women's mosques, where women traditionally serve as imams. It is the largest traditionally Muslim ethnic group in China.
Though it is the most common meat in China, the Hui and Uyghur peoples' general adherence to Islam means they mostly avoid this meat, the only one considered categorically haram.
Wangjia Hutong, the oldest surviving women's mosque, is in this Chinese city, whose Chief Rabbi offered Matteo Ricci his position if Ricci quit eating pork.

bonuses.leadin: The first of "Six Principles" of this school of thought is that politics "is governed by objective laws that have their roots in human nature." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this school whose "classical" form draws on the work of Reinhold Niebuhr. Kenneth Waltz advocates a newer variant of it.

This thinker gave the "Six Principles of Political Realism" in his book Politics Among Nations. Another book by this author states that the achievement of freedom is the title Purpose of American Politics.

The second principle of political realism describes interests defined in terms of this concept, which refers to the ability of an agent to influence other countries. This concept, whose "soft" kind refers to non-coercive international influence, is held by an "Elite" according to a C. Wright Mills book.
answers: political realism [or neorealism or classical realism; accept word forms like neorealist]
formatted_answers: political realism [or neorealism or classical realism; accept word forms like neorealist]

bonuses.leadin: Upper-convected time derivatives are often used in nonlinear formulae modelling these materials, such as the Oldroyd-B model. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these materials described by the Kelvin-Voigt and Maxwell models, both of which can be visualized using a circuit composed of springs and dashpots.

Viscoelastic materials can experience creep, in which constant values of stress can lead to increases in this quantity. The Young modulus equals stress divided by this quantity, whose axial form is the change in length per unit length.
Phenomena like creep mean that stress-strain curves for viscoelastic materials typically include "loops" named for this phenomenon, which are also often seen in plots of demagnetization.

bonuses.leadin: An unnamed character in a James Weldon Johnson novel decides to perform this action after seeing a Southern mob burn a man alive. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this action. Helen Oyeyemi cited a Nella Larsen novel titled for this action as inspiration for writing a novel centered on a girl obsessed with mirrors.

This retelling of Snow White by Oyeyemi opens with a girl running away from her abusive father, Frank Novak. At the Whitman family's Thanksgiving dinner, this novel's White first title character asks her dark-skinned daughter to beat her as punishment for sending her away.
A writer kills off all his protagonists in an Oyeyemi novel titled for one of these animals. A "fantastic" one of these animals steals chickens from Boggis, Bunce, and Bean in a Roald Dahl novel.
answers: passing for White [or equivalents mentioning pretending to be White or not Black]
formatted_answers: passing for White [or equivalents mentioning pretending to be White or not Black]

bonuses.leadin: Frequent typos and long series of identical punctuation marks are often used in a parodic Facebook group whose members "pretend to be" these people. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these people born between about 1946 and 1964. A common dismissive phrase prepends this generation's name with the word "OK."

"A group where we all pretend to be boomers" has been likened to the "digital" form of this activity, whose practitioners physically act out characters in formats and cosplay inspired by games like Dungeons and Dragons.
The language used in the group was termed "Boomerspeak" by this Canadian linguist, who cohosts the podcast Lingthusiasm with Lauren Gawne and who wrote the book Because Internet.
answers: baby boomers [accept A group where we all pretend to be boomers; accept OK boomer]
formatted_answers: baby boomers [accept A group where we all pretend to be boomers; accept OK boomer]

bonuses.leadin: The waste material produced by these devices is called swarf. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these machining devices, in which an object is rapidly rotated around an axis of symmetry.

Metal lathes can be used to produce these simple machines, which have a helical pattern around the outside which fasten them into a surface. Namesake "drivers" are used to tighten these devices into a surface.

Lathes can be used to produce this pattern of parallel or crossed lines on a metal surface, which is often applied to the handles of tools in order to give better grip. A very hard namesake "roller" is more often used than namesake "cutters" to produce this pattern.

bonuses.leadin: Kent Bach argued that these things operate on the "specification assumption" that "that"-clauses do not just describe these things. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these things, the subject of "anti-substitution intuitions." Frege's second puzzle says that coreferring names are not always substitutable when applied to these things.
This philosopher discussed non-substitutable coreferring names in "A Puzzle about Belief." This philosopher criticized the descriptivist theory of names in his Naming and Necessity.

In Naming and Necessity, Kripke shows that a posteriori statements can also necessarily have this property. Plato's Theaetetus (THEE-tuh-tuss) defines knowledge to be a justified belief with this property, which is possessed by facts.

bonuses.leadin: This play's opening claims that "music has charms to soothe a savage breast." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this only tragedy by William Congreve, which elsewhere notes that "heav'n has no rage, like love to hatred turn'd."
The Mourning Bride is now best remembered for an oft-misquoted phrase from Act 3, Scene 2, which notes that hell has "no fury" like one of these people. A specific two-word phrase is required.
The Mourning Bride exemplifies this period's theater. William Wycherley's The Country Wife is one of the "comedies" named for this period, during which Charles II returned to the throne.
answers: a woman scorn'd [or "nor hell a fury, like a woman scorn'd"]
Restoration theater [or Restoration period; or Restoration comedy; or Restoration drama]
formatted_answers: a woman scorn'd [or "nor hell a fury, like a woman scorn'd"]
Restoration theater [or Restoration period; or Restoration comedy; or Restoration drama]

bonuses.leadin: Tories and Reformists clashed over a visit by this man to Bytown, leading to the Stony Monday Riot. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man, who gifted the Coiled Dragon to Tokugawa Iemochi (toh-koo-GAH-wah ee-em-oh-chee). In 1860, this man ordered a building destroyed upon hearing of the death of The Times correspondent Thomas William Bowlby.
Elgin ordered the burning of the Old Summer Palace during the second of these conflicts between Britain and China named for an addictive drug.

This man called the burning of the Old Summer Palace "vandal-like" in a letter to his sister. After the death of Frederick Townsend Ward, this man led the "Ever Victorious Army" against Taiping rebels.
answers: James Bruce, 8th Earl of Elgin [or Lord Elgin; or James Bruce]
Charles George Gordon [or "Chinese" Gordon; or Gordon Pasha; or Gordon of Khartoum]
formatted_answers: James Bruce, 8th Earl of Elgin [or Lord Elgin; or James Bruce]
Charles George Gordon [or "Chinese" Gordon; or Gordon Pasha; or Gordon of Khartoum]

bonuses.leadin: This composer's percussive piano sonata, as well as his Out of Doors, Nine Little Piano Pieces, and first piano concerto, were all written in his "piano year" of 1926. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this composer whose other piano works include Allegro barbaro and the six-volume Mikrokosmos.

Analyzing Bartok's music inspired Erno Lendvai's "axis system," which can assign functions to keys via axes drawn on a circular pitch space ascending by this perfect interval clockwise, and by fourths counterclockwise.

Bartok's second piano concerto, like his fourth and fifth string quartets, uses this form exemplified by sections ordered "ABCBA." Ternary form also exemplifies this symmetric form, named after an architectural element.

bonuses.leadin: Ugunskrusts are also known as this deity's namesake cross. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this sky god in Slavic mythology who constantly warred with the lord of the underworld, Veles.
Perun uses this weapon to attack Veles whenever he tries to steal Perun's cattle. Another sky god, Zeus, primarily uses this weapon that is accompanied by thunder.

Description acceptable. According to some stories, Perun owned a bird named Slava who prominently had this physical trait. A now-disputed myth states that a creature with this physical trait was sent to the Great Sky Spirit to help alleviate a winter.
answers: multi-colored [accept descriptions like having many colors or rainbow-colored; accept Rainbow Crow]
formatted_answers: multi-colored [accept descriptions like having many colors or rainbow-colored; accept Rainbow Crow]

bonuses.leadin: In the essay "On Influence," this author claimed that, despite admiring Ernest Hemingway, Hemingway's stories weren't an influence on his minimalist style. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of the short stories "Where I'm Calling From" and "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love."

Carver's minimalist style was inspired by Gordon Lish, who told Carver to use five words in place of fifteen while writing stories for this publication. This publication published an article about a depressed singer who gets ill a month before his fiftieth birthday.

In an interview, Carver claimed that unlike much of his minimalist fiction, this story "affirms something." In this story, a Renaissance documentary inspires the weed-smoking narrator to hold his blind guest's hand as they draw the title building.

bonuses.leadin: These materials are called amalgams when they contain mercury. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these metallic substances that are composed of two or more elements, examples of which include brass and steel.

Brass is an example of a substitutional alloy, while carbon steel is an example of this other type. Atoms of different radii form a type of alloy named for this term, which is also used in crystallography for a certain type of point defect.

This scientist is the namesake of a type of crystallographic defect that consists of a vacancy defect and a nearby interstitial defect. One-dimensional dislocations in crystal structures can be described by a model named for this Soviet scientist and Kontorova.
answers: Yakov (Ilich) Frenkel [or Jacov (Il'ich) Frenkel; accept Frenkel defects or Frenkel–Kontorova model]
formatted_answers: Yakov (Ilich) Frenkel [or Jacov (Il'ich) Frenkel; accept Frenkel defects or Frenkel–Kontorova model]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following related to DJ Larry Levan's "Saturday Masses" at New York's Paradise Garage.
parts: Levan was perhaps the most influential DJ of the era named for being "post" this ubiquitous late-1970s dance music genre, whose artists included Donna Summer and the Bee Gees.

Levan's emphasis on the rhythm section was one of his many influences from this style whose producers included King Tubby and Lee "Scratch" Perry. This style, which originated as instrumental versions of reggae tracks, names a reverb-heavy offshoot of UK garage pioneered by Digital Mystikz and Datsik.

Levan is credited with pioneering this dance music genre's "garage" subtype. Chicago's Frankie Knuckles is the "godfather" of this genre, whose soul-inflected "deep" subgenre was developed by Larry Heard.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about famous historical sisters.
parts: In this modern-day Southeast Asian country, the Trung sisters led a rebellion against occupying Chinese forces of the Han dynasty, and may have drowned themselves in the Red River after being defeated.

These abolitionist sisters, who also advocated for women's rights, were born in South Carolina, became Quakers, and wrote personal narratives for the 1839 book American Slavery as It Is: Testimony of a Thousand Witnesses.

Six sisters with this maiden name were the daughters of Lord Redesdale (REEDZ-dail). One of these sisters married the fascist Oswald Mosley, and another who was close with Adolf Hitler shot herself in the head in 1939 when Britain declared war on Germany.
answers: Vietnam [or Socialist Republic of Vietnam; or Cộng hòa Xã hội chủ nghĩa Việt Nam]
Grimké sisters [or Sarah Moore Grimké and Angelina Emily Grimké; or Sarah Moore Grimké and Angelina Grimké Weld]
Mitford [or Freeman-Mitford; or Diana Freeman-Mitford; or Unity Valkyrie Freeman-Mitford]
formatted_answers: Vietnam [or Socialist Republic of Vietnam; or Cộng hòa Xã hội chủ nghĩa Việt Nam]
Grimké sisters [or Sarah Moore Grimké and Angelina Emily Grimké; or Sarah Moore Grimké and Angelina Grimké Weld]
Mitford [or Freeman-Mitford; or Diana Freeman-Mitford; or Unity Valkyrie Freeman-Mitford]

bonuses.leadin: In 2021, Raimer Dunke and his research team claimed to have observed this organism entangled with a quantum bit. For 10 points each:
parts: Name that organism that entered a state of cryptobiosis after being cooled down to the temperature quantum bits are typically stored in.
Quantum entanglement is hypothesized to help birds detect the Earth's magnetic field for this practice performed during the changing of the seasons.
Quantum entanglement is also suggested to be behind this process' nearly 100% efficiency. One experiment indicated excitons used quantum walks when traversing chromophores during this process.
answers: migration [prompt on less specific answers such as moving or flying]
formatted_answers: migration [prompt on less specific answers such as moving or flying]
